verses.text: In the seventh month, on the twenty-first day of the month, the word of the LORD came through Haggai the prophet, saying:
verses.comment: The seventh month is Tishri, aligning with the Feast of Tabernacles. This reveals that God's command comes amid an important festival season.

verses.text: "Speak now to Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and to Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, and to all the remnant of the people, and say:
verses.comment: The term 'remnant' points to the faithful who returned from exile—a concept echoed throughout both Testaments (Isa. 10:20–22).

verses.text: 'Who is left among you who saw this house in its former glory? And how do you see it now? Does it not seem as nothing to you?'
verses.comment: The comparison to Solomon's temple highlights the disappointment and longing for restoration—themes central to God's ongoing plan for His people.

verses.text: 'But now, be strong, Zerubbabel,' declares the LORD. 'Be strong, Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest. Be strong, all you people of the land,' declares the LORD. 'Work, for I am with you,' says the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: Echoes God's encouragement to Joshua (Josh. 1), underlining divine presence. The repeated address of the high priest points to the deep connection between leadership, liturgy, and restoration.

verses.text: 'According to the word I covenanted with you when you came out of Egypt, so my Spirit remains among you. Do not fear!'
verses.comment: Refers to the Sinai covenant and the abiding presence of God's Spirit, pointing forward to Pentecost (Acts 2:1–4).

verses.text: For the LORD of hosts says this: 'Yet once more, in a little while, I will shake the heavens and the earth, the sea and the dry land.'
verses.comment: The language of 'shaking' signals divine intervention. Hebrews 12:26 interprets this as a prophetic sign of the coming of God's unshakable kingdom.

verses.text: 'And I will shake all nations, and the Desire of all nations will come, and I will fill this house with glory,' says the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: 'The Desire of all nations' is often seen as a Messianic prophecy, fulfilled in Christ who brings the nations to God (cf. Matt. 2:1–2; John 1:14).

verses.text: 'The silver is mine, and the gold is mine,' declares the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: Reminds the people that all material resources belong to God. Spiritual priorities are greater than outward riches.

verses.text: 'The latter glory of this house will be greater than the former,' says the LORD of hosts, 'and in this place I will give peace,' declares the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: Prophetically points beyond the temple’s physical splendor to the spiritual peace brought by Christ (John 2:19–22).

verses.text: On the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, in the second year of Darius, the word of the LORD came to Haggai the prophet, saying:
verses.comment: Marks a new prophetic message, emphasizing the importance of set times and seasons in God's plan.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'Ask the priests about the law:'
verses.comment: Shows the special authority given to priests for teaching and discerning the law (Lev. 10:10–11).

verses.text: 'If someone carries holy meat in the fold of his garment and the fold touches bread, stew, wine, oil, or any other food, does it become holy?' The priests answered, 'No.'
verses.comment: Explains the principle that holiness is not automatically transferred through indirect contact.

verses.text: Then Haggai said, 'If someone who is unclean because of contact with a dead body touches any of these, does it become unclean?' The priests answered, 'It does become unclean.'
verses.comment: Illustrates that impurity spreads more easily than holiness—an important spiritual lesson about ritual and moral purity.

verses.text: So Haggai answered, 'So it is with this people, and with this nation before me,' declares the LORD, 'and so with every work of their hands; and what they offer there is unclean.'
verses.comment: Highlights the need for true spiritual purity before God, beyond mere ritual observance.

verses.text: 'Now, consider from this day onward. Before one stone was laid upon another in the temple of the LORD,
verses.comment: 'Consider' is a repeated command for self-examination regarding obedience and blessing.

verses.text: how did you fare? When you came to a heap of twenty measures, there were only ten; when you went to the wine vat to draw fifty measures, there were but twenty.
verses.comment: Reflects covenant curses for disobedience—shortage and frustration.

verses.text: I struck you with blight, mildew, and hail in all the labors of your hands, yet you did not turn to me,' declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Judgment serves as discipline, calling Israel to repentance. God's correction is a sign of His fatherly care.

verses.text: 'Consider now from this day onward, from the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, since the day that the foundation of the LORD’s temple was laid, consider:'
verses.comment: Again emphasizes the importance of significant dates in salvation history; the foundation-laying signals a new beginning.

verses.text: 'Is the seed yet in the barn? Indeed, the vine, the fig tree, the pomegranate, and the olive tree have not yielded fruit. But from this day on I will bless you.'
verses.comment: The promise of blessing follows obedience. Fruitfulness responds to God’s favor, reminding us that grace and blessing flow from fidelity.

verses.text: The word of the LORD came a second time to Haggai on the twenty-fourth day of the month, saying:
verses.comment: Another revelation on the same day, highlighting the urgency and richness of God's communication.

verses.text: 'Speak to Zerubbabel, governor of Judah, saying, I am about to shake the heavens and the earth
verses.comment: Reiterates God's cosmic intervention, with Zerubbabel as a symbol of hope and continuity.

verses.text: 'and to overthrow the throne of kingdoms. I will destroy the strength of the kingdoms of the nations, and overthrow the chariots and their riders. And the horses and their riders shall fall, every one by the sword of his brother.'
verses.comment: Mirrors God's past deliverances (Exodus). Anticipates a final eschatological victory over evil powers.

verses.text: 'On that day,' says the LORD of hosts, 'I will take you, O Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, my servant,' declares the LORD, 'and will make you like a signet ring, for I have chosen you,' declares the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: The 'signet ring' recalls royal authority. Zerubbabel becomes a symbol of God’s chosen servant and foreshadows the royal Messiah (see Matt. 1:12–16).
